data.text: The unprecedented rise of deficits and public debts during the pandemic has led to large and widespread deviations from fiscal rules, testing the rules’ credibility. https://t.co/k1AnMstyGY #IMFBlog https://t.co/19uOBWJRoa

Following a surge in the second half of 2021, we expect inflation to average 3.9% in advanced economies and 5.9% in emerging market and developing economies in 2022, before subsiding in 2023. https://t.co/8UTMqlIzzx #IMFBlog
How can China🇨🇳 advance its recovery and ensure balanced, inclusive, and green growth? Find out more in our annual health check of the Chinese economy: https://t.co/UznnCIsmuR https://t.co/c8a1KTlYhx

IMF staff and Argentine authorities reach an understanding on key policies as part of ongoing discussions of an IMF-supported program. Work towards a reaching Staff-Level Agreement will continue, with final agreement on a program arrangement subject to IMF’s Exec. Board approval. https://t.co/1CYcREoWXI

Low inflation-adjusted interest rates spur investors to take more risk, boosting stock prices, but a jump in rates could send shares tumbling. Our new #IMFblog has more. https://t.co/wMKvbRytfx https://t.co/geqjxKLwj8

The continuing global recovery faces multiple challenges as the pandemic enters its third year. Find out how this will affect global growth in our new World Economic Outlook video. https://t.co/XIAa9fVOTt #WEO https://t.co/Wz6Ev3N1Ab

A consumption-led growth model would support China's 🇨🇳 continued recovery in the short term and deliver high-quality growth in the long run. Find out more in our latest Country Focus: https://t.co/o7bagASaso https://t.co/P2aqSmXkjf

China's 🇨🇳 recovery from the pandemic is well advanced thanks to strong & swift policy actions, including a high vaccination rate, but the economy’s rebound lacks balance & momentum has slowed. A transition to balanced, inclusive & green growth remains key https://t.co/Ga2ZNk8Kpi https://t.co/dxRJWtOn4n

The 🇯🇵Japanese economy is recovering from the pandemic with strong policy support and high vaccination levels. The recovery continues to gain momentum in 2022, but risks are tilted downwards. https://t.co/bj70ssD5Jx https://t.co/rJ5XZbsgni

Only 4% of people in low-income countries are fully vaccinated versus 70% in high-income countries. We need to break the hold of the pandemic with widespread vaccination, testing, and access to therapeutics.

Germany🇩🇪: 3.8%

Spain🇪🇸: 5.8%

The advanced economies group will grow at 3.9% in 2022 and 2.6% in 2023. The downgrade is partly because of continued COVID and supply disruptions and earlier withdrawal of monetary accommodation. More here: https://t.co/XIAa9fEduT #WEO https://t.co/Km2K6MiJ2H

IMF staff analysis suggests that supply disruptions shaved 0.5–1.0 percentage point off global GDP growth in 2021 while adding 1.0 percentage point to core inflation. Details in the just-released #WEO. https://t.co/XIAa9fEduT https://t.co/d213BkPASi

Mobility restrictions and labor shortages from the rapid spread of the Omicron variant, supply disruptions, record debt, rising inflation, and changes to policy are some of the challenges weighing on the global economy. https://t.co/XIAa9fVOTt #WEO https://t.co/eYx2z01S7D

We have revised down the global growth projection for 2022 to 4.4%, 0.5 percentage points lower than our October forecast.

Inflation will likely persist for longer but subside in 2023, assuming inflation expectations remain anchored to the targets set by central banks. We expect energy and food prices to grow at more moderate rates in 2022. https://t.co/WtC6xWDqsb #WEO https://t.co/9rzv0jZjQk
